channel.title: Java Runtime Viewer
channel.description: I'm looking for a program that allows me to view the java classes or information about the classes and fields/methods at runtime. Would be much appreciated. ;)

item.title: Java Runtime Viewer
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Load the applet with cherokee, then you have the object that extends applet, send that into Reflection Buddy, and then navigate around with the mouse until you find what you wanted. If you want to know how to load the applet, have a look at cherokee, look at the docs or even one of the at least 3 examples.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Runtime Viewer
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Load Applet with Cherokee and inject code:

abraham2119:

it’s just a couple of instructions you’d be injecting (‘NEW’ java/lang/Exception, ‘INVOKEVIRTUAL’ java/lang/Throwable/printStackTrace()) at the beginning of the method. all you have to do after that is reset instruction pointers (offset them by +6)

then pass the results to a ReflectionBuddy handler to make a map of the loaded objects, then use ReflectionBuddy to route through and see the value…

but, I was not being comical before, I was totally serious, [quote=“Ollie, post:33, topic:345568”]You don’t know a lot do you? You need to know what object you want, no computer application yet can determine what you want before you do, we would need to re-construct your brain in a computer simulation and give it all the same it all the same experiences you have had, then maybe we can determine what you actually want.[/quote]

Read full topic

Since there is no program capable of doing this then I suggest this topic be closed before I have to embarrass any flamers

item.title: Java Runtime Viewer
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Justin186:

No thats what I thought I needed at first, however what I need to do is trace back to the original initialization of the object which calls the method to get the object that I actually want the instance of.

Load the applet with cherokee, then use reflection on that object to get ahold of the object you want, then send that into the ‘reflection explorer’.

Or you could simply send in the original object to the ‘reflection explorer’ and navigate to what you want.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Runtime Viewer
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Justin186, post:22, topic:345568”]I don’t have the Applet, I’ve just got the .Jar File which runs it.
Do you think Cherokee would be appropriate to do what I would need to do in my example, because Its set up similarly except a lot more classes and methods to mislead.[/quote]

Again, what is this jar file? If there is any class that extends Applet in there then cherokee can run it, cherokee doesn’t care where the applet class comes from, the hard drive, a website, the moon, outer space, it just cares that there IS an applet class.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Runtime Viewer
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Justin186:

The only reflection explorers ive found work only for runescape… I want one that can load ANY jar folder and view the fields and stuf at run time.

Justin186:

I’ve already looked at Cherokee and can’t see how it is appropriate to the current situation so please stop posting unless you have a solution to my problem

Cherokee can load and run any APPLET, and if you send the instance of Applet you are using into the ReflectionBuddy class it will allow you to view all of the fields with values, and change most of them if you want.

Now if what you are trying to explore isn’t an Applet, and instead an application, you can’t use cherokee but can still start it running any way you please and send in the object to ReflectionBuddy and do the same things as above.

If you need any help post some more details here and we can try to help more.

Read full topic

Abraham, is there any programs that can hook into a java process and do so?

Read full topic
